Issues.Title: fix(ivy): maintain coalesced listeners order
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, listeners order was not preserved in case we coalesce them to avoid triggering unnecessary change detection cycles. For performance reasons we were attaching listeners to existing events at head (always using first listener as an anchor), to avoid going through the list, thus breaking the order in which listeners are registered. In some scenarios this order might be important (for example with `ngModelChange` and `input` listeners), so this commit updates the logic to put new listeners at the end of the list. In order to avoid performance implications, we keep a pointer to the last listener in the list, so adding a new listener takes constant amount of time.

This PR resolves FW-1528.

Issues.Title: ngcc: Ideas for potential future improvements/refactorings
Issues.Body:
This is a random list of potential future improvements/ideas/suggestions to consider/explore for `ngcc`, mostly related to our goal of speeing it up (as a follow-up to #32427).

Jira issue: [FW-1543](https://angular-team.atlassian.net/browse/FW-1543)

---

**Architecture / Refactorings**

- [ ]  
> I believe that this could move inside the `Executor`. That way we can actually create a different updater for master and slave, rather than having an intelligent one that needs to care about the `cluster` API.

By: @petebacondarwin
Source: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/32427#discussion_r319765730
PR: -

##
- [ ]  
> In fact I think that having a `ClusterMasterExecutor` and `ClusterWorkerExecuter` would be a cleaner way to architect this. I think it would require moving a lot of the helper functions in the file into an abstract `BaseExecutor` class, but I think this would also be helpful in terms of making this big main file more manageable.

By: @petebacondarwin
Source: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/32427#discussion_r319765969
PR: -

##
- [ ]  
> Investigate whether we need to take available memory/memory consumption into account, when calculating how many worker processes to spawn?
> - How is memory affected by worker processes?
> - What happens, when available memory is exceeded?

By: @gkalpak
PR: -

---

**Speed improvement**

- [ ]  
> **Pete:** From what I read, the main difference (only?) between `cluster.fork()` and `child_process.fork()` is that they share TCP connections? But since we are not interested in acting as a server, isn‚Äôt that redundant?
>
> **George:** Yes, we could use `child_process.fork()`, but `cluster` is a little more convenient (e.g. we don't need to provide the executable and argunents to `.fork()`, we can listen for messages on all workers with `cluster.on()`, it exposes `cluster.isMaster`/`cluster.isWorker`, etc.).
If there is extra overhead to `cluster`, I would expect it to be fixed (so not worth doing the bookkeeping manually), but we can definitely try (so that we don't have to assume :smiley:).

By: @petebacondarwin 
Source: https://angular-team.slack.com/archives/CB4UC1932/p1567284254046600

##
- [ ]  
> One thing [...] to try is to make the JS file that is executed by the worker process much slimmer. Currently the whole of the ngcc program must be reloaded into the node.js process (including requiring and parsing all the dependent JS files). I found in dgeni that this can be quite a significant initial hit if the program is large.

By: @petebacondarwin 
Source: https://angular-team.slack.com/archives/CB4UC1932/p1567354022059300

##
- [ ]  
> BTW2, we could also investigate whether `worker_threads` work better for `ngcc`. They are supposed to be more lightweight than separate processes and can communicate more efficiently with the main thread via shared memory. (But they are experimental and available behind a flag before 11.7 iirc.)

By: @gkalpak
Source: https://angular-team.slack.com/archives/CB4UC1932/p1567245751039000
PR: -

More context:
If the speed improvement is significant, we could detect support for `worker_threads` and use that implementation if it is available and fall back to other implementation (e.g. `cluster`-based) if not.

##
- [ ]  
> BTW, I believe we can get another ~2x improvement by only processing the entry-points we care about, instead of processing everything by default with ivy-ngcc.

By: @gkalpak
Source: https://angular-team.slack.com/archives/CB4UC1932/p1567237731035500
PR: -

More context:
Currently, in order to take advantage of the speed improvement achieved through parallel task execution, one needs to run `ngcc` "stand-alone" (not implicitly via `@angular/cli`). The easiest way to do that using the `ivy-ngcc` node script.

The default (e.g. with `npm run ivy-ngcc`) is to process all supported formats (even if they won't be used). This takes much more time than necessary. As a rouch estimate, the difference between `yarn ivy-ngcc` vs `yarn ivy-ngcc -p es2015 module` (which are the properties that `@angular/cli` essentially [cares about](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/e0073c0210547cd8e502fcd47a6cb6976f02b572/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/browser.ts#L69-L70)) is 2.5x faster on my laptop for `aio`.

I believe it would make sense to get people to only compile the properties they care about by default. This would require to:
1. Recommend this in documentation and/or have `@angular/cli` auto-generate a suitable `postinstall` npm script when scaffolding IVy apps.
2. Determine the format properties we need to consider, based on the cli targets (and the `mainFields` used from the current version of `@angular/cli`). There are potentially going to be two sets of properties; one for es2015 and one for es5.
3. Add support for compiling the first of two sets of `propertiesToConsider` (or run `ngcc` twice, once for es2015 and once for es5, but that would be significantly slower, I assume).

##
- [ ]  
> Investigate potential performance bottlenecks (e.g. why only a 2x/2.5x improvement via parallelization).
> Incorporate tracking of various metrics (possibly with a special flag only, to avoid affecting performance) to help gain better insight on current performance/issues. Examples:
> - Track time spent on master.
> - Track time spent on IPC (e.g. by including timestamps in messages).
> - Track worker idle time.
> - Track tasks processed per worker.
>     - Track mean processing time.
> - Cached file-system cache hits/misses.

Issues.Title: fix(language-service): use tsLSHost to do module resolution
Issues.Body:
This is a patch PR for https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/32479

This PR fixes a critical performance issue where the language
service makes a MASSIVE number of filesystem calls when performing
module resolution.
This is because there is no caching. To make matters worse, module
resolution is performed for every program change (which means every
few keystrokes trigger a massive number of fs calls).

There are two solutions here:

Provide a cache to ts.resolveModuleName()
Use ts.LanguageServiceHost.resolveModuleNames()
Since every Project (and by extension ConfiguredProject) implements
ts.LanguageServiceHost interface, (2) is the preferred solution here.
i.e. the TypeScript LanguageServiceHost always has the
resolveModuleNames() defined even though it's optional in the interface.

Issues.Title: ng e2e - Protractor's browser.baseUrl Doesn't Match baseHref Build Option Anymore
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [x ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 7.1.3 ### Description When running `ng e2e` before with a `baseHref` specified as an option in the `build` that was ran for `ng e2e` it produced a protractor `browser.baseUrl` that ended in a `/` but now in Angular 8 it does not. Meaning using a `baseHref` of `/ext/` back in v7.1.3 made `browser.baseUrl` return `http://localhost:4200/ext/` when running `ng e2e` but now in Angular 8 using a `baseHref` of `/ext/` makes `browser.baseUrl` return `http://localhost:4200/ext`. That missing `/` at the end is a very important difference. So the real problem here is that back in Angular 7.1.3 my e2e were passing while making use of the `baseHref` build flag and now they are not in latest Angular 8 version. The reason why they are not passing is because `await browser.get('connect');` should navigate to `http://localhost:4200/ext/connect` but instead it is trying to navigate to `http://localhost:4200/connect`. This is because the `browser.baseUrl` is `http://localhost:4200/ext` and if you go into the [code of Protractor](https://github.com/angular/protractor/blob/5.4.1/lib/browser.ts#L859) you will see that it uses `browser.baseUrl` with the `url.resolve(...)` method. And `url.resolve('http://localhost:4200/ext', 'connect');` returns `'http://localhost:4200/connect'`. Note: my Angular.json build has this for the baseHref: `"baseHref": "/ext/"` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Create a new Angular 8 project 2. Modify the angular.json file so that the basic build option uses a `baseHref` of `/ext/` 3. Add routes, pages, and components so that `http://localhost:4200/ext/connect` is a valid page 4. Update `app.po.ts`'s `navigateTo()` method so that you use `return brwoser.get('connect');` 5. Run `ng e2e` 6. Observe that you get a 404 error because it tries to navigate to `http://localhost:4200/connect` instead of `http://localhost:4200/ext/connect` ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: build: do not include material prebuilt theme twice in legacy tests
Issues.Body:
Just something I noticed while investigating the MDC slider test failures on Edge BS..

Apparently we include the Angular Material prebuilt theme twice in the
legacy Karma tests. This is because we also generate a second folder
called `esm5` in the package output (for later use in the release
composing step). This folder also contains the prebuilt themes as
a side-effect of copying the assets for esm5 inlining/bundling.

In any case, we should not import the theme using a glob, but rather
use an explicit path (similar to how we do it for the mdc theme).

Issues.Title: Deleting mat-tab-link from links array removes selected tab's focus
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-cjny6b
Steps to reproduce:
1. Third tab "TestActiveTab" is currently active.
2. Click "Delete Index(1)" to delete second tab.
3. Tab "TestActiveTab" is no longer displayed as active.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
When the tab before "TestActiveTab" was deleted, I expected "TestActiveTab" to remain active since activeLink is still set to "TestActiveTab".

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
Looking at [tab-nav-bar.ts](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/tabs/tab-nav-bar/tab-nav-bar.ts) 
```
 @Input()
  get active(): boolean { return this._isActive; }
  set active(value: boolean) {
    if (value !== this._isActive) {
      this._isActive = value;
      this._tabNavBar.updateActiveLink(this.elementRef);
    }
  }
```
The tabnavbar is only prompted to update when this._isActive !== value. So in our case, we have "TestActiveTab" tab set to active at index(2). Then we delete the second tab. "TestActiveTab" now has an index of 1 but the selected index is still set to 2. Since TestActiveTab's value never changed, the tabNavBar never changes it's selected index and "TestActiveTab" does not appear active, even though it's active property is still set to true. 

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.4
- CDK/Material: 8.1.4
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Deleting mat-tab-link from links array removes selected tab's focus" (#16971)

Issues.Body:
